_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary

Facility:    West Central AGRIServices, LLC. - Adrian
Location:    S. 71 Hwy., Adrian, Mo.
Contact:     Randy Morris
Phone:     816-297-2138


1. The Facility Policy

West Central AGRIServices, LLC. and the employees of the West Central AGRIServices, LLC. located south of Adrian are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Adrian Fire Department, and other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2. Facility Information

The primary activity at the facility is the receiving, storage and distribution of bulk dry/liquid fertilizer and anhydrous ammonia for direct application as a crop nutrient and agricultural chemicals. The facility also handles grain.

The facility has four 30,000-gallon storage tanks, one 18,000-gallon storage tank, one 12,000-gallon storage tank and could have up to four 34,300-gallon railcars on site at one time. The facility also has (33) 1,000-gallon nurse tanks, five 1500-gallon nurse tanks and one 560-gallon applicator tank for product distribution.

3. The Accidental Release Prevention Program.

The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1, 1981", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc., the Missouri Anhydrous Ammonia Law and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".

4. The Five-year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that: have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

5. The Emergency Response

Program.

The facility has a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA
Standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;

The facility provided State and Local authorities with the emergency
planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);

The facility has a written emergency response program, in accordance with OSHA Standard, 29 CFR 1910.120, including pre-emergency planning and employee training.

6. Planned changes to improve safety.

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. The facility has been evaluated for compliance with the 1999 ANSI K61.1 Code and improvements will be completed in the near future.
